div.head: Act 1st
div.stage: Scene 1st-- A quiet valley at the foot of the Hartz Mountains. Cottage of Dame Barbara R. H. 3rd Ent. with practicable upper window and balcony. Set tree beside cottage, at back Set arbor L.H. 3rd ent. Broken water and low rustic stone bridge or long rocky trail piece, with platform from R. to L. backed by an extended range of hills or mountain spurs above which light clouds appear, illuminated by the reflected light of the moon. Shortly after rise of curtains the moonbeams grow faint and the ruddy glow of the rising sun diffuses itself over the clouds and horizon.

Music () at rise of curtain--enter Rodolphe, at back, R. H. He descends, comes forward, and after looking cautiously around, claps his hands three times beneath the window. The upper window opens and Amina appears on balcony.

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Surely I heard his well-known signal. Hist, who's there?

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Tis I, Rodolphe!

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Rodolphe! Hush speak low, if my foster mother still sleeps, I will join you. (retires.)

div.stage: #Music# () Rodolphe goes upstage and looks cautiously off, then comes down -- Amina enters from cottage.

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Rodolphe!

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: My own!

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: When did you return?

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: 'Twas past midnight: although wearied and footsore I could not sleep until I had seen you.

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Oh, how wearily the days and nights have passed since you left me! What kept you so long?

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Ill fortune, Amina. After reaching Gottingen and finding no purchaser for my picture I heard that there was a wealthy traveller at Cassel, collecting works of art. I had but four silver florins in my pocket, yet I hopefully set out to meet him. After journeying five whole days I arrived at Cassel only to find that the traveller had departed two days before.

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: And your beautiful picture -- upon which so much of our future was built -- you have brought it back?

No. Crushed in my last hope to obtain the means necessary to our union I left itmy picture with a remorseless agent for a pittance barely sufficient for subsistence during my journey homeward, and here I am without a single guilder in my pocket, and what is worse if I fail to redeem my pledge at the end of two months, it is lost to me forever.

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: (Aside) Poor, dear Rodolphe, he knows not the worst--the heaviest blow is yet to come, How shall I break it to him? (Aloud) Dear Rodolphe, my great joy at seeing you made me forget for a moment that which I fear to tell you.

div.stage: (The moonlight begins to fade and the horizon grow ruddy with the rising sun.)

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Fear to tell me! Speak, what has happened?

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Be calm and listen. Last week I attended the Festival of St. John, Be calm and listen! last week I attended the Festival of St. John, where I was observed by Count Wolfenstein-- the all powerful Lord of this wide domain--the next day was an evil one to us my Rudolphe, for it brought him here to this poor cottage; to tell my foster mother, that he loved me! in company with the other members of the village choir. Upon raising my eyes after we had finished the anthem I found a dark, strange man gazing upon me. A moment after he quitted the spot. I enquired who he was and learned that it was the Count Wolfenstein, the all powerful Lord of this wide domain.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Although I met his gaze but for a moment, I felt that it boded evil to me--to us.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Evil! Evil to us?

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Yes, evil, Rodolphe, nor were my fears idle, the next day brought him here to our humble abode--he told my foster- mother that he loved me.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: (Starting) Loved!--You?

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Yes, and that we should no longer dwell in obscurity--that we should be removed to the castle--that masters should be provided for my suitable education, and in a year I should take the place of the late Countess of Wolfenstein.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: And dame Barbara?----

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Joyfully consented. This very day is set apart for our removal. The escort will be here at sunrise.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: And you, Amina, You?---

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: I supplicated, wept, remonstrated, but you know, dear Rodolphe, I am powerless.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: (Vehemently) By Heaven, you shall not go.

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Hush, be calm, dear Rodolphe.

div.stage: (Dame Barbara appears on the balcony)

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: I sayBy Heaven! you shall not go! Were he twenty times more potent I would oppose his power to the last.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Eh, what, varlet, hussey, only wait till I get down! #Music#() She disappears from balcony and enters from door) What, jade, ingrate! how dare you? Is this your gratitude? Where is your pride? You, the most noble Countess of Wolfenstein that is to be, meeting young men in secret and on the very day of your bethrothal. Oh, if his high mightiness the Count should find it out!

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: But mother --

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Not a word, how dare you? In with you, into the house, in I say!(Forces her into the cottage, closes the door, then turns to Rodolphe) So, beggar, you've come back, have you? How dare you show your unlucky face here at such a time as this! I had hoped you'd fallen into the hands of the conscript officers and gone for a soldier, or better still, been carried off by the demons of the Brocken.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: And yet you see I've escaped both. Hark ye, dame. I love Amina, she loves me, you yourself promised that she should be mine as soon as I could command a hundred silver crowns.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Pah, that was before I knew her value, but now that I do know it and others know it too, I've changed my mind. But where are the hundred crowns? Where's the fortune you were to get for your great painting? I warrant me you haven't got a single groschen of it. Come, let me see the hundred crowns.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: My picture is not yet sold.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Ha, ha. Did I not say so! Not yet sold, eh? Here's a pretty fellow, that would take a young girl from her comfortable home, a good bed, sweet milk and egg-pudding, to lodge her on pea-straw, and feed her at best on black bread and sour cheese. Oh, was there ever such villainy?

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Nay, but listen to me.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: And you beggar Not a word; begone, do you think people of quality have nothing to do but listen to beggars complaints? And above all at such a time as this? Begone, I say, this is to be a festival day, the maidens of the village will be here anon; the grand escort will be here, headed by the Count's Chamberlain, aye, and his Lordship the Count himself will be here, to bear the Countess that is to be and her right honorable foster-mother that is to be to the Castle. #Music#() Hark, here come the villagers already, Out of the way I say.

div.stage: (Pushes him rudely aside, goes up and looks off RH. Rodolphe retires into the arbor.)

Enter lively from RH at back, female villagers with garlands, followed by males, two of whom bear a rustic chair, festooned with flowers. They descend and come forward, greeting the Dame. Females L.H. males R. at back. The sun appears above one of the spurs)

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Ah, you are early, friends.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Yes, but not earlier than the sun, for see, it is already peeping over the great toe of the Brocken. But where's Amina?

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: (Drawing herself up) The Countess that is to be is preparing to receive his lordship the Count. But never mind her Ladyship, Enjoy yourselves until she is ready. Here, CasperWagner, here I am, come with me and bring some refreshment while I help to prepare her ladyship (Goes into the cottage followed by Casper and Jan. The two latter re-enter with white cloth, wine, fruits, etc. which they arrange on table beneath the tree)Well upstage out of the way.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Bless me,Bless us and Save us!--What a long tail our host has got! how grand Dame Barbara has grown, to be sureall on a sudden! If she goes on at this rate the wide halls of the grand old Castle of Wolfenstein will be a world too small to hold her. I hope this piece of good fortune will not make suchas great a fool of our dear 'Mina

sp.speaker: Rosetta
sp.p: I don't understand this, I thought 'Mina was bethrothed to the handsome young painter Rodolphe, what ever could have become of him?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Oh, 'tis said he has gone for a soldier. But come friends, while 'Mina is making ready let us rehearse our Festival Dance.

div.stage: Music() Grand Garland Dance by principals and full Ballet, during which the Males gather around the table and eat and drink. After dance, Barbara re-enters extravagantly dressed, wearing a monstrous cap ridiculously trimmed)

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: There! Having completed her ladyships toilet I have attended to my own, and, if I know anything about dress, I flatter myself that my appearance would do honor to any occasion. (Displays herself)

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Mercy on us, was there ever such a frightjay! Why she looks for all the world like a great horned owl dressed up in the cast-off fineryfeathers of a peacock. Ha, ha, ha, Did you ever? ObserveJust you watch me tickle the old buzzard. (Aloud and with affected admiration) Why, Dame Barbara, is that you?

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: (Drawing herself up)Of course it is, child. Who else should it be? (Aside) I knew I should make them open their eyes.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Why you've almost taken away my breath. I declare, Dame, you're looking gorgeous! So young and girlish too. At first I thought it was Amina! Indeed, if I were 'Mina--I beg pardon, I mean her Ladyship, I wouldn't care to have you in the way when his lordship the Count arrives.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: And why not, pray?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Because I should consider you a dangerous rival.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Nonesense, girl, you don't think so.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Indeed, Dame Barbara, I was never more serious in my life. (Laughingly confers with Rosetta and villagers)

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: It's strange I never noticed it before, but that girl Carline is a very sensible person. Music () Ah, here comes the escort!

div.stage: (All go up and look off R.H. Rodolphe glides from the arbor into the cottage unobserved.)

Enter from R.H. and descending. Von Puffengruntz, bearing his wand of office, preceded by two servants of the Count's household. As he comes down the Male Villagers take off their caps and the females curtsey

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: (L.H.) With pompous condescension) Be covered, good people, be covered; the air of the valley is yet damp. We never insist upon ceremony at the expense of health. (Aside) Ahem It is the true policy of greatness to occasionally waive a point of etiquette in dealing with inferiors.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: What a courtly gentleman!

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: What an imposing female!

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: (Curtseying) Your Excellency is welcome.

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: (Bowing) I cannot be mistaken, I was just about to inquire, but that stately presence and graceful dignity tell me that I am addressing Madam Barbara.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: (Curtseying) Oh, sir. (Aside) How one's manner will betray one, I always said I belonged to a higher sphere.

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: I come, Madam, by the Count's order to announce that the cavalcade has arrived and is now resting on the plateau, beyond the ravine. His lordship will be here presently, and in person conduct your fair foster-daughter to her palfrey, that waits without, impatient for the honor to be mounted by her.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: (Curtseying) Oh, sir, his lordship is so considerate. But may I inquire if I have been thought of? Am I also to be provided with a becoming escort? Is there any palfrey without impatient for the honor to be ridden by me?

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: That shall be my privilege

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: (Astonished) Eh!

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: That is I have charged myself with the especial honor of being your escort.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: (Curtseying very low) Oh! (Music ()

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: He comes! Room there for his lordship.

div.stage: (Villagers range themselves R. to receive the COUNT who enters R.H. at back, crosses and comes down L.H. preceded by guards and followed by Wulfgar and Bruno. When down Villagers shout and wave their caps. Puff. remains upstage with Villagers R.C.)

sp.speaker: Wolfenstein
sp.p: Salutation to the good Dame Barbara.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: (Curtseying very low) Oh, your lordship!

sp.speaker: Wolfenstein
sp.p: And how fares your lovely charge?

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Well, may it please your lordship, quite well, a little nervous from over-anxiety to see your lordship, but that's quite natural with us poor silly things, I suffered dreadfully in that way when my poor dear, dead and gone Christopher courted me. Many and many a time---

sp.speaker: Wolfenstein
sp.p: (Impatiently interrupting her) But the fair Amina,

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Is quite ready and dying to see you, I will present her to your lordship at once.

div.stage: (She is going into the cottage when Rodolphe appears and comes forward, leading Amina by the hand. (CHORD)

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Allow me dame Barbara, to do the honors.

sp.speaker: All the Villagers
sp.p: Rodolphe! (Picture of astonishment)

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: My Lord Count Wolfenstein, permit me, Rodolphe Werner, a poor artist, to present to you Amina, foster-daughter to Dame Barbara, a free maiden of the valley and my affianced bride.

sp.speaker: Wolfenstein
sp.p: Who is this madman?

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: N-n-n-n-nobody, your Lordship, that is a poor, weak simpleton who imagines he is betrothed to every girl in the village. As your lordship truly says, a madman.

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: A madman! Mercy on us, we shall all be murdered. Seize him, secure him, somebody, everybody!

div.stage: Music() Wulfgar and Bruno seize Rodolphe and after a struggle overpower him. C. Amina screams, clings to him for a moment then throws herself at the Counts feet, he raises and passes her to Barbara, then turns to guards.

sp.speaker: Wolfenstein
sp.p: Release him, (They release him) His misfortune claims our pity. Let some of his fellows conduct him hence and see that no harm comes to him.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: (Defiantly) My Lord Count---

sp.speaker: Wolfenstein
sp.p: Begone, Sirrah!
Come, Rodolphe, come with me. (aside) Are you indeed mad to brave the tiger in his lair--(Leads him RH) Come I say, this is neither time nor place to right your wrong. Be calm, I say, be calm.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: (Shaking him by the hand) You are right, Casper, you are right. (Looks scornfully at Wolfenstein) Come, my friend, come. (Exit R.H. 1st Ent. with CasperWagner)

sp.speaker: Wolfenstein
sp.p: 'Tis he, the lover. He would braves me, too?eh?
Wulgar!
When the procession moves Track younder knave, take Bruno with you. Seize him, but let no eye see you, Place him in the secret vault beneath the eastern wing. Once there--you know the rest.

sp.speaker: Wulfgar
sp.p: (Nods meaningly) I understand. (Gives sign to Bruno and is going R.H. 1st Ent.)

sp.speaker: Wolfenstein
sp.p: Stay, not now, it will be noted. When the procession moves then steal away by the upper path

div.stage: (Wulfgar nods, turns upstage and confers with Bruno. Wolfenstein confers with Von Puffengruntz at back.)

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p:
(Leading Amina forward R. of C. and aside to her)
Silence, on your life, not a word that you have ever seen him before. If the Count were to know---Mercy on me, I tremble to think of it, there wouldn't be a head left on any of our shoulders.

div.stage: (Birds heard singing till scene closes)

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: (Waving his wand) Let the procession move!

div.stage: Music () Wolfenstein joins Amina. Villagers bring foward the festooned chair from L.H.U.C. Wolfenstein assists Amina into the seat. The chair is borne by four villagers, the others form in procession. Wolfenstein beside the chair, Von Puffengruntz pompously leading Barbara by the hand. Wulfgar and Bruno loiter behind and when unobserved steal off R.H.U.C. The procession after making the circuit of the stage ascends the rocks L.H. and crosses R.H., the VILLAGERS singing the following

lg.l: Hark, hark, hark!
Hark, the birds with tuneful voices,
Vocal for our lady fair,
And the lips of op'ning flowers
Breathe their incense on the air,
Breathe their incense on the air.
See, see, see!
See the sun in orient splendor
Gilding every glittering spray ,
Busy weaving jewelled chaplets
For our lovely Queen of May,
For our lovely Queen of May.
Mark, mark, mark!
Mark the plumes of mighty Brocken
Waving in the fragrant air,
Proudly nodding salutations
To our charming lady fair,
To our charming lady fair.

div.stage: (Closed in when procession clears 1st grooves)

div.head: Scene 2nd
div.stage: A dark woody or rocky pass (in 1) Lights half down.
Music () Enter Wulfgar + Bruno R.H.

sp.speaker: Wulfgar
sp.p: So, we've reached the pass a good five minutes before him.

sp.speaker: Bruno
sp.p: But if he should cross the bridge?

sp.speaker: Wulfgar
sp.p: Aye, if, but he'll not. I watched him from behind "The Devil's Hump" and saw him part company with that lout at the foot of the old cross. I tell you his path lies this way. (Crosses to L.H.) Hark some one comes. (Looks cautiously off) Ha, I was right, 'tis he, quick conceal yourself, and when I hood the hawk stand ready to clip his claws.

div.stage: (Music () Wulfgar conceals himself L.H. Bruno R.
#Music#() Enter Rodoplhe, L.H.)

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Deeper, let me plunge, deeper still into the heart of the mountains. The light of the sun falls like molten lead on my aching eyeballs. My heart's on fire. My brain is in a whirl, I strive to think, but thought becomes a chaos, Am I awake or is this some horrible dream? Water! Water! My throat is flaming! Ha, yonder's a rill trickling from the rock.

rdg.stage: Music. () He is going R. when Wulfgar, who has stolen from his concealment, throws a cloak over his head, while Bruno at the same moment pinions his arms, Rodolphe struggling violently

#Music# Rudolph is going R. when Wulf. steals behind him--but hearing his steps turns and sees his intention--Rudolphe draw, "Ah! Vile miscreants! base hirelings of a Tyrant two upon an unsuspecting man!--" Combat. He fights both, disarms Bruno--then drives Rudolph Wulfgar into the Corner. Bruno then takes the cloak L.C.

sp.speaker: Wulfgar
sp.p: Quick, quick, the cord, the cord: he has the strength of a lion.
sp.stage: (Bruno draws a cord tightly over his arms.)
sp.p: So, away, away!

div.stage: (Music. They force Rodolphe off RH.)

div.head: Scene 3rd
div.stage: Study and Laboratory of The Black Crook. (in 2) Hertzog discovered L.H., seated at table poring over a large cabalistic book. Greppo pinched and starved asleep on stool R.C. before a retort furnace in R.H. flat. An antique lamp illuminates the characters of the book upon the table, uponon which is a skull and hourglass--Door on L.H. flat. Transparent window in R.H. flat.
Music () at opening of scene.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.stage: (Rising in pain and with difficulty he closes the book and comes forward)
sp.p: Vain, vain! Some subtile spell is hovering in the air, that mocks my power and makes the charms that once were potent, a jabbering, idle sound. And shall I yield to this invisible? I, Hertzog, the Crook, whom men call Sorcerer. I, at whose name the strong man trembles and the weak grows faint. I whose life of long, laborious years hath well nigh run its course, gleaning dark knowledge in forbidden paths, shall I now seek the light? My eyes are old and dim and could not brave the glare. No, no, I'll work new mines, new mines, and plumb the depths of darker mysteries still.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: (Turning) How now, knave?

p.stage: (Starts from his sleep and uses the bellows rapidly at the mouth of the furnace)

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Come hither, varlet.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Yes, master. (puts down bellows and comes forward, yawning)

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: What, drone, sluggard, drowsing again?

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: N-n-n-no good master, no.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Out, lying knave, did I not hear thee snore?

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Snore? Aye, granted, but 'twas in thy service, master. Much fasting and long watching caused this left, rebellious eye to wink, and so I snored to wake it up again.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Bah! shuffling loon, thy drowsing comes of overfeeding.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: (Viewing himself) Overfeeding? Look I if I were overfed? A scanty chopin of weak sour beer with one poor groschen's worth of musty beans is all the banquet this shrunk belly knows from week to week.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: What, rogue, dost grumble?

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: No, good master, no.

div.stage: (Rumbling thunder) Music () Tremolo piano

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Ha, the night grows foul. 'Tis all the better, Bring me my cloak and staff #Thunder#

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Bringing forward crutch stick and short, black hooded cloak from nail on flat They are here. (Places cloak on Hertzog's shoulders

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: So, now thine own.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: My cloak, I have none, Master.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Thy cap.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Mine?

sp.speaker: Herzog
sp.p: Thine. #(Thunder)#

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Oh, Lord, what a night, (brings his cap from peg beside the furnace)

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Bring with thee yonder brazen casket.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Th-th-the brazen casket?

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Aye, echoing fool! #(Thunder)#

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: (Tremblingly goes to table and takes casket) (Aside) The devil's tool chest (Aloud) Whither go we, dread master?

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: To the Serpents' Glen. (#Loud thunder)#

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p:
(Starting) Oh Lord! The Serpents Glen! Beelzebub's favorite chapel! Surely, good master, you would not, and above all on such a night as this?
(#Thunder and lightning,# the latter showing itself in transparent window on R.H. flat) Hark how the tempest howls. Strong pines are toppling down the mountain sides. 'Twere certain death to go abroad tonight.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Silence and follow. (Goes toward door. #lightning and loud thunder#)

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p:
(Who has made a movement to follow, starts back trembling violently.)
Master, I-I cannot!

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: (Turning fiercely) What, ingrate, do you rebel?

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: No, master, no, my spirit's willing, but my legs are weak.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Wretch, did I not snatch thee drowning from the whirling gulf, bind thy torn limbs with rare medicaments and stanch the current of thy ebbing life that fast was running out?

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: You did, good master, you did. (Aside) Out of the water into the fire.

sp.speaker: Herzog
sp.p:
Begone!
#Music forte#() Throws open the door in L.H. flat. Loud crashing thunder and vivid lightning. Greppo starts back. Fool, begone, I say! (Seizes and hurls him toward the open door. Heavy thunder and lightning. Greppo in doorway entreats. Hertzog raises his staff) Away, away!

div.stage: Thunder and lightning--Exeunt door in L.H. flat
Close in

div.head: Scene 4th
div.stage: An apartment in the castle of Wolfenstein. (in 1) #Low thunder#. Lights up. Enter Carline, R.H.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Bless me, what a night to welcome her ladyship that is to be, to her new home. I declare the old castle trembles and shakes like a great ship at sea. (#Loud Thunder#) Mercy on us. What a crash! But pshaw, why should I care how the tempest rages without. Am I not safe within? And in rare good luck too? Only to think that I should be chosen from among all the girls in the village to become Amina's companion and own particular waiting maid. Old Hagar, the gypsy fortune teller, whose palm I crossed with a new quarter florin last week told me that good fortune awaited me, and, sure enough, here it is. Only to think of it, that I, Carline Brenner, who for ten long years have been chained to a stupid spinning wheel day and night should become confidential companion to the future mistress of Wolfenstein. Was there ever such good fortune? I declare, I am so happy I could sing for a month.

div.stage: (Introduced song + Exit L.H.)
Lights down. Change slow.

div.head: Scene 5th
div.stage: A wild glen in the heart of the Brocken. Perilous rocky pathway leading from above at back, L.H. to stage. Returning crosses over a rock 5 feet high R.H. 3rd Ent. with set blasted tree. Large working Raven on limb and vampyre doors in trunk. Set rock-piece in centre, on stage, opposite 2nd grooves, bearing a general resemblance to a rude altar. Set trick plants with serrated leaves R.+L. of Set altar small rock tail pieces R.+ L. in 1) The whole stage is much broken up with rocky sets--leaving the center back of the altar generally open--Lights down.

#Music# at opening(). Hertzog appears above L.H. followed by Greppo, tremblingly. They cross from L. to R.H. cross on rock in front of blasted tree and descend slowly. Greppo making several efforts to turn back is checked by a gesture from Hertzog.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p:
(Coming forward L.H. when down)
Oh Lord, what a place! #Music#() THE Raven croaks, flaps its wings and shows red illuminated eyes. Starting What's that? (Turns) 'Twas the croaking of yonder monk-raven. Did'st hear, master, 'tis an evil sign. Let's begone.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Silence, fool. Set down the casket.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: I will.

Thank St. Michael, I'm rid of that pleasant companion. As I have an empty belly and hope some day to have it filled, I could swear before the Burgomaster that when we passed over the bridge of Belzebubs Nose I heard voices laughing inside that very casket, saw blue blazes come out of the keyhole and smelt a strong smell of brimstone.
sp.stage: (Music() The Raven croaks as before) Looking fearfully around)
sp.p: Oh Lord, oh Lord, what a pleasant place for an uninterrupted funeral. Ugh!

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Knave.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Master.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Bring hither fuel.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: I obey. (aside) Here's a chance! If I can only get out of this, may the Fiend singe me if he catches me back. I'd rather be on the raging flood than serve him an hour longer. (Is about to ascend the rocks)

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Whither go you, varlet?

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: For fuel, master. This around us is wet with the storm and will not burn. As we came along I noted beneath the shelter of a crag, hard by, many dry faggots. I will fetch them. (going)

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Come back.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: The dead branches of yon blasted larch will serve.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: But, master--

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Dolt, obey me.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: I'm gone!

div.stage: #Music#() Hertzog goes slowly up to set altar and smites it three times with his crutch stick. Blue flame issues from the top of the altar and continues during the scene.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Here are the faggots, master.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: 'Tis well. Feed yonder flame.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: A flame! How came we by a flame? I'll swear I brought no tinder-box. More brimstone I suppose. Oh Lord, oh Lord!

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Fool, do as I command.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p:
I fly.
#Music#() He goes slowly and timidly up to and behind altar with faggots.) Now for some devils cookery.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: So: pluck me an inner leaf from yonder adder plant.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: I knew it. Vegetable broth.

div.stage: (#Music#() He approaches the plant L.H. and is about to pluck a leaf when it opens suddenly and discovers a dwarf demon around whose body is twined a huge green serpent with flaming eyes, distended jaws and forked tongue, as the leaves open the head darts at Greppo threateningly. He starts back, uttering a cry of alarm- the leaves close.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Ha!

div.stage: (Stamps his foot angrily and points to the plant. R.H. Greppo tremblingly crosses to R.H. and is about to pluck a leaf from the plant when it opens and the same action of dwarf demon, serpent, + Greppo as before--Leaves close.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: So, so! Bring me the green flagon from yonder casket.

div.stage: #Music#() Greppo goes to casket L.H. and raises the lid, when fire flashes from the box. He starts back in an agony of fear and crossing sits upon the small set rock piece. R. H. 2nd Ent, when flames shoot from the stone and he springs into the air, uttering a sharp cry of pain.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Baffled at every turn! Begone, knave, thy presence mars my work.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Most willingly. (Is about to ascend the rocks)

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Not there.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Keep watch without from yonder crag that overhangs the gorge.
Should straggling footsteps wend this way give timely warning.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: (Aside) Straggling footsteps! Straggling indeed to be abroad on such a night, and least of all in such a place as this.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Did'st hear me?

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: I vanish

div.stage: #Music#() Hertzog describes a circle and figures on the ground (C) with his crutch stick, after which the end of the stick ignites and burns with a faint blue flame. He then describes figures in the air, during which latter action he speaks.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Skuldawelp, familiar, slave of my power, I invoke thee.

div.stage: #Music#() A spectre in filmy drapery with Death's head, luminous eyes, moveable jaw, and skeleton hands, works on from R.L.H.U.E. to C. Illuminated by light from medium.

sp.speaker: Skuldawelp
sp.p: Your will.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Break the malignant spells that thwart and mock me. Bind fast my hidden enemies. Restore to me my lost power.

sp.speaker: Skuldawelp
sp.p: I cannot, an adverse spell has crossed me, my power is spent, all that was mine is thine. Zamiel alone can serve thee.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: (Shrinking) Zamiel!

sp.speaker: Skuldaewelp
sp.p: Zamiel!--Dismiss me!

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Begone!
Zamiel! No, no. I dare not invoke his fearful aid.
I-I-Ha, what tremor's this! My blood grows icy cold, my limbs are failing, a film is gathering over my eyes.
Can this be death? Death! No, no. I cannot, I will not die. Save me, save me, Zamiel! Zamiel!
sp.stage: #Music forte()# He drags himself toward the casket, seizes it, rises with difficulty and totters to the altar, at the foot of which he places the casket, opens it and brings forth a packet containing four lesser packets and begins the following:

lg.l: By a bloody murder done
Gainst a mother by her son!

sp.stage: He casts red ingredient into the fire. #Wild burst of demoniacal music#() A huge, green serpent, with moveable jaw, raises from the flame behind the altar and strikes viciously at Hertzog. The Raven croaks, flaps its wings and shows red illuminated eyes. The leaves of the adder plants open and disclose demons and serpents as before. Skeleton forms appear above on rocks, pointing to Hertzog. Music changes to tremulo piano() The adder plants remain open during remainder of scene.

lg.l: By the venomed tounge that 'stills
Poisoned slander till it kills!

sp.stage: Casts green ingredient into the fire, Wild blast of demoniacal music and same action as before--music changes to tremulo piano.)

lg.l: By the thief with skulking tread,
Who breaks the grave and robs the dead!

sp.stage: (Casts blue ingredient into the flame. Wild blast and same action as before. Music changes to tremulo piano.()

lg.l: By all the crimes men hate and fear,
Zamiel, master, now appear.

sp.stage: Casts red ingredient into the fire.
sp.p: Zamiel, appear! appear!

div.stage: #Wild blast# and same action as before, in addition to which loud crashing thunder and vivid lightning, the latter showing in luminous forks in backing. Huge serpents writhe to and fro across the stage. Zamiel, bearing a sceptre, around which is twined a green serpent, suddenly appears from trunk of blasted tree, with strong light from medium thrown upon him. He holds the picture for a moment before speaking. Hertzog kneeling down L.H.--Music stops.

sp.speaker: Zamiel
sp.p: Arise!
Why am I summoned?

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: My life is waining. Give me to live, feed the dull current of my sluggish veins. Give me fresh charms and potencies.

sp.speaker: Zamiel
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Men hate and did they not fear would despise me. I would repay their hate with hate. I would live on, on, on, and in that life rival thy dread power of Evil.

sp.speaker: Zamiel
sp.p: What wilt thou give for such a boon?

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Whate'er thou wilt, give me but life and all I have is thine.

sp.speaker: Zamiel
sp.p: 'Tis not enough. What's thine is mine already.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: What else?

sp.speaker: Zamiel
sp.p: Listen. A soul younger, fresher, whiter than thine, must on each recurring year be, by thy arts, turned to my account.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: I hear, dread master, and will pay the price.

sp.speaker: Zamiel
sp.p: For every soul thus lost to good and gained to me a years new life is thine. A single soul a single year. A hundred souls a hundred years. 'Tis with thyself to live forever.

sp.speaker: Herzog
sp.p: Forever!

sp.speaker: Zamiel
sp.p: Forever! But should the stroke of midnight fall a twelve-month hence and no lost soul, by you betrayed within that time, come wailing at my gates, perdition closes on your dark career--Is't a compact?

sp.speaker: Herzog
sp.p: It is.

div.stage: Music(). Zamiel waves his sceptre. Thunder and lightning-- a fiend (Redglare) rises through trap, L.H.--Red fire--bearing a large red book, pen and inkhorn.

sp.speaker: Zamiel
sp.p: (Pointing to book) Sign!

div.stage: #Music#. Thunder and lightning. Sheeted spectres arise through traps at back and appear at L.+R. from behind rocks. Skuldawelp reappears L.H. 3rd Ent. Demons and skeletons appear from R + L, all pointing at Hertzog who takes the pen and dips it in the horn. The pen ignites and flames blue, he writes in the book, during which the Raven croaks, flaps its wings, &c. Serpents writhe to and fro and demoniacal laughter is heard outside and above. After he has signed Zamiel waves his sceptre, gong sounds, and Redglare descends with book, etc., amid red fire. Music stops#Curtain#

sp.speaker: Zamiel
sp.p: Tis well. Listen slave, within a dungeon of the eastern wing of gray and gloomy Wolfenstein, there lies in chains a youth called Rodolphe. His fortune's desperate, and desperate souls, like drowning men, wil catch at straws. Begin with him.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p:
Dread power, I hear thy mandate and thy will obey.
(Bows low before Zamiel)

delSpan.stage: Music() Thunder + Lighting and all the action as before. Red fire from behind altar and at wings. Redglare reappears R.H. 2nd Ent., pointing to Hertzog. Winged serpents appear above and firey dragon enters L.H. 2nd Ent., simultaneous with which Greppo very white with hair on end rushes on R.H.1st Ent. as if to communicate something)

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Master, I--

delSpan.stage: (Is appalled at the sight before him, utters a loud cry, falls upon his knees, clasping his hands and moving his lips rapidly as if in prayer.

div.stage: Quick Curtain

div.head: Act 2nd
div.stage: Scene 1st: A subterranean vault beneath the castle of Wolfenstein (in 2) Set floor R.H. 2nd Ent. Moveable panel in upper part of R.H. flat. Sliding stone panel in lower part of L.H. flat. Wulfgar discovered chaining Rodolphe discovered, chained to wall of R.H. flat. Music() at rise of curtain--Lights 1/2 down.

sp.speaker: Wulfgar
sp.p: There my fine fellow. I think you're both safe and comfortable. No intruders--neither light nor sound ever comes here. This should have been your lodging last night, but you see I mislaid the key.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Wretch.

sp.speaker: Wulfgar
sp.p: When you want exercise or change of air and you can manage to get rid of yonder little incumbrances. (Pointing to chains) You can take it in the vault beneath your feet. Yonder trap leads to it. You may find it a little mouldy and may stumble over the skeleton of the last lodger, but that's nothing. Any change is better than no change at all.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Monster, begone.

sp.speaker: Wulfgar
sp.p: Oh, certainly, anything to oblige. In the mean time if your exercise should give you an appetite and you should want food and water cry out for it, cry loud and it won't come. Ha, ha ha! Good night.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Alone! So ends in darkness and in death all my bright dreams of the future, and must I perish thus--I who have but entered the portal of life? No, no, it cannot be! I must, I will burst these bonds. (Music() He makes an effort to break the chains.) 'Tis vain, they defy even the strength of despair. (Shuddering) How awful is the chill of this noxious vault, its icy vapors press upon my brow like the clammy hand of Death, and freeze my very marrow. (Music() Hertzog enters with dark lantern through sliding panel in L.H. flat) (Starting) Who's there?

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Thy friend.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p:
(Turning light upon his own face) Behold!
(Chord)

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: (Starting) Hertzog, the Crook!

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Aye, so men call me. (Puts lantern off 2nd Ent. L.H.)

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Ill-omened bird, what brings you here? Yet why should I ask? You come the minister of death? 'tis well, 'tis merciful, begin your work.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Out, foolish boy. I serve no human master.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Then why are you here?

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: I come to give thee liberty.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Liberty!

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Aye. Listen. I hate thine enemy, thou lov'st a maid of whom thou hast been robbed. Would'st win her back? I have the power to aid thee.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Begone, tempter. I know your power and can guess from whence it comes. Men say you deal in dark and necromantic spells that warp the senses and enthrall the soul.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Pah! Art thou, too, tainted with the vulgar fear that calls philosophy--the natural working of great Nature's laws--a spell of darkness? It is the light, weak boy, the light, which we sage men, who waste our lives oe'r midnight lamps, glean from dull vapors for the sluggards' use. Fools sneer the most when least they understand and brand as foul what Nature stamps as fair.--Thy chains gall thee, let me loose them. (He touches them with his staff--they fall to ground)

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: What is your purpose?

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Again I say to serve thee.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Listen, I will tell thee a secret. She whom thou lovest is of noble birth.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Amina?

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Aye, yet not Amina, but the only child and heiress of the noble house of Wellenstein stolen when but an infant by a revengeful gypsey whom her father scourged and given to gabbling Barbara.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Amina noble!

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Aye, and thou of humble birth, but gold can buy nobility-- nay more, can give thee power to cross thine enemy.win Amina for thy bride!

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Why talk to me of gold--to me, the poorest of the poor? Whose purse contains not half so much as one poor silver mark.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Thou'rt poor indeed, but thou art poor because thou wilt be poor. 'Tis with thyself to shame the wealth of the mighty Croesus.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Hast thou not heard of glittering gold in massive piles fast locked within these mountains?

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: An idle tale, a senseless fable told by croning gossips. A treasure often sought but never found and some do say 'tis death to seek it.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: I tell thee, boy, the story's true, this gold is palpable to sight and touch, and mayt be garnered too, if thou art bold enough.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: I'll hear no more! Thou'dst take advantage of my desperate strait to work some juggle to entrap my soul. Begone, I say, begone!

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: And leave thee to thy doom?

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: And thy affianced bride--would'st thou so like a craven yield her up unto thine enemy?

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Oh, agony!

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: 'Tis true she loves thee, but bethink thee boy, she is but woman and she may be won. Her noble birth is known to Wolfenstein who means to wed her, and with her fortune to prop his falling house. Already flattered by his serpent tounge, she dries her tears and listens to his suit.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: 'Tis false!

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: 'Tis true!

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: The proof?

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Behold.

div.stage: (Music() He waves his staff. A panel slides in upper part of R.H. flat slides open, showing through gauze Wolfenstein and Amina, the former clasping the hand and kneeling at the feet of the latter whose face is half-averted. Picture strongly lighted.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: (Starting toward it) By Heaven, he shall not!

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: (Interposing, waves his staff--panel closes) Bravely said, bravely said!

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: What devilish compact would you have me sign? Propose it while my reason whirls and desperation aids your dam'd design. If by the act I snatch her from his grasp, I'll pay the ransom though it reach my soul.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Come, philosopher or Fiend! Whate'er thou art, the price, I say, the price.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Pah! I ask no compact, I would serve thee gratis. I but demand that thou shalt serve thyself. Be rich and thou'lt be powerful. In thy revenge upon thine enemy and mine, thou'lt pay thy debt to me with interest.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Where lies this wondrous treasure?

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Listen. Amid the fastnesses of the Hartz, beyond the outlet of the Black Gorge lies a small lake, whose waters few have ever gazen upon, for vulgar fear and superstitious dread have long since marked it for enchanted ground.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: I've heard the story.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p:
Trace carefully its northern shore, until a rock, rising like a wall, bars further passage. Beneath a fringe of tangled vines you'll find a boat concealed. Behold this talismanic ring!
(Takes a large ring from his finger)
'Tis a magnet of wondrous power. When thou hast found the boat step boldly in, this ring will guide thee safely to the entrance of the goldern cavern within the compass of whose glittering walls thy wondering eyes may feast on wealth far greater than the coffers of the world can boast.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Give me the ring.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: 'Tis thine! (gives ring) Stay, thou'lt need a henchman. (Stamps his foot) Varlet come forth. (Music() Panel on L.H. flat slides as before, and Greppo enters). (Aside) He too shall perish.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Your will, Master?

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: To part with three.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: (Aside) Oh, if this should be but true. (Aloud) With me?

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: With thee, knave.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: I weary with thine appetite.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: (Aside) Here's a chance! Oh here is a chance, if he but stick to it. I must seem unwilling lest he repent. (Aloud) Dear master, I will reform, believe me, I will reform, allowance me to what would starve a mouse. Nay, more, to pleasure you, I will not eat at all, I'll live on air, but do not cast me off.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: I am resolved. Behold thy future master. (to Rodolphe) Thou'lt find him faithful, but he breeds a famine. Take for thy present need this purse of gold. (Offers purse, Rodolphe by a gesture refuses it.) Nay, when thou'rt rich thou canst repay it.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Nay, more, if what you say be true, eternal gratitude---

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Pah! You trifle time. (Moves his staff, the panel opens) Yonder lies your path, it is a golden one, begone.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Farewell, come boy, come. #Music#() Exit at panel. Greppo following turns to entreat Hertzog, who raises his staff threateningly. Greppo exits hurriedly at panel)

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: (Stands in opening and chuckling gazes after them) The thought of vegeance stirs within his heart, the lust of gold is rising in his soul, the path that leads to where tis hoarded ends in death. He's mine, ha, ha! He's mine.

div.stage: Closed In

div.head: Scene 2nd
div.stage: A lobby in the castle of Wolfenstein (in 1) Enter Barbara R.H. followed by Carline.)

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Don't talk to me, girl. Remember your station and consider mine. Who am I and what am I that I should be lodged in a wing of the castle overlooking the dog kennels?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Your ladyship is quite right to rebel, and when I advised your ladyship to calm yourself it was out of consideration for your ladyship's eyes. Any little flurry does so spoil the natural beauty of their expression.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Carline, you're a good girl, you're a considerate girl and I forgive you, but eyes or no eyes, I'll not be imposed on. Where's Mynheer Von Puffengruntz? Where's his Lordship's Chamberlain?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p:
(Looking L.H.) Here he comes down the great stairway, as full of flesh and scant of breath as ever.
(Aside) And as the waddling old porpoise appears to have a liquorish tooth for this silly old buzzard, I'll leave them to bill and coo while I run off to comfort dear 'Mina who has passed the whole night in tears for poor Rodolphe.

div.stage: (Von Puff enters L.H. CARLINE curtsies and exits L.H.)

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: Eh, what, Madam Barbara, stirring so early! Why, bless my soul, the mist of the mountain is yet hanging upon the turrets of the castle.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: There let it hang and be hanged to it! Stirring indeed! Haven't I been stirring all night. Has not her ladyship been stirring all night and wouldn't the seven sleepers have been stirring all night, too, if they had lodged where I did?

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: Surely nothing has had the audacity to disturb the quiet of your slumbersyou?

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Nothing! To begin with, do you call such a storm as that of last night, nothing? Why the thunder creashed over the castle loud enough to wake the dead. That was bad enough, but only to think that I, the right honorable foster mother that is to be, to her right honorable ladyship that is to be, passing the night in apartments overlooking a dog kennel.

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: A dog-kennel?

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Aye, a kennel of great, savage hounds, fed late at night on raw meat by their one eyed keeper on purpose to give them the nightmare and make them dream all night long of chasing wild boars in the forest. Ugh! I shall never get their horrible yelping out of my head.

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: Believe me, my dear Madam Barbara, it is the first time the brutes ever were known to have been unruly. I promise you that they shall be soundly punished and instantly removed. But I too am criminal. The apartments were selected by me because they command the best view of the mountains.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: But I don't want to look at the mountains. I got a glimpse of it from one of the North windows last night during the storm, and it looked for all the world as if Beelzebub and his imps were holding a jubileee there.

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: Enough, my dear Madam Barbara, enough. If the mountain is unpleasant it shall be removed. No, no! I mean you shall be removed. (Approaching her in a wheedling manner) Will it please you to accompany me and choose for yourself?

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: (Simperingly) Really, Mynheer Von Puffengruntz, you have such mollifying ways that--that--

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: Oh! o-o.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Would it be prudent? Dare I trust myself? We poor silly things are so weak and you men are so naughty that--that-- (Leans her head upon his shoulder, looks up into his face and sighs)

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: Confiding innocence, rely upon the honor of a Von Puffengruntz. (Looks around, sighs, kisses her. She utters a faint scream and hiding her face in her fan is led off L.H. by Von Puffengruntz chuckling)

div.head: Scene 3rd
div.stage: A wild pass in the Hartz mountains (in 1) Music() at change of scene. Lights down. Enter R.H. Rodolphe and Greppo, each bearing an Alpine staff--Greppo in improved condition.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: A strange weird place, and one, it seems, not often tred by human footsteps. I fear we've missed the way. What think you, Master Greppo?

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Master Greppo! Master Greppo! He calls me Master Greppo! Here's an honor and here's a master. Oh such a master! Such a liberal master, as this stuffed belly, tight as any drum with goodly provender and generous wine will testify. (To Rodolphe) What think I, princely master?

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Why since you honor me with consultation and give me leave to think at all--a privilege grown rusty from great lack of use- I say we're right, and that the lake we seek is near at hand.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Why think you so?

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Because just now I heard a bittern cry, and twice ere that I heard a marsh-frog croak, and as they're both accounted water-fowl, 'twere safe to say that we're near the water.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Then let us on. (Crossing to L.H.) Ere long the rising moon will pierce this veil of mist and light us to our golden haven. Come. (Exit L.H.)

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: I follow (Exit L.H.)

div.stage: Change very slowly
No whistle

div.head: Scene 4th
div.stage: The Grotto of Golden Stalactites--A grand and comprehensive water cavern of gold, deeply perspective, with Stalactiform arched roof, cut wings, representing vistas, running parallel and harmonizing with that of the main grotto, the mouth of which (5 feet high by 5 feet wide) discloses an open lake and distant shore at back. Set transparent silver waters, in which are seen sporting fishes and nondescript Amphibea. Diminutive fairies asleep on the waters of the grotto in golden shells. Set ground or shore-piece richly studded with gold and jewels. Set masses of emerald and gold R, L, + C., upon and at the foot of which are reclining Gnomes and Amphibea. Fairies asleep in poses R + L. The Moon, seen through the opening at the back and over the distant shore of the lake, shows red upon its face at the opening of the scene.

Music at change. Shortly after which Dragonfin who has been asleep on a jewelled mass on the shore, Centre, slowly awakens, rises and stretches himself. Upon turning he sees the red upon the face of the moon. #Music#() Chord().

sp.speaker: Dragonfin
sp.p: Awake! Awake!
sp.stage: #Music#() Hurry. Gnomes and Amphibea spring to their feet. Fairies and water nymphs enter hurriedly R + L. Diminutive sprites in shells and fairies poses awaken)
sp.p: Behold! There's blood upon the face of the Moon, our Queen's in danger, To arms! To arms!

div.stage: #Music#() hurry--the sprites in the shells disappear R + L. The Gnomes, Amphibea and Fairies rush off R + L and immediately re-enter armed, the two first named with knotted clubs and tridents. The fairies with javelins. During the action the red disappears from the face of the moon and it resumes its natural color.

sp.speaker: Dragonfin
sp.p: Stay, 'tis past. Hark.

div.stage: All bend forward and listen)

sp.speaker: Dragonfin
sp.p: 'Tis she, our queen.

div.stage: (All kneel. Music() Stalacta rises C. from the water and steps on shore, assisted by Dragonfin)

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Arise, my loving subjects.

div.stage: (All rise)

sp.speaker: Dragonfin
sp.p: Mistress, but now the light in yon great Sapphire died out and stains of blood flushed in the face of the pale moon. You have 'scaped some deadly peril?

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Thou art right. Listen all, tonight while wandering in the fastnesses of the Hartz without my protecting talisman, I heedlessly trod within one of the charmed circles of our enemy, the Arch-fiend Zamiel.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: On the instant I was transformed into a white Dove, with shorn pinions,--From beneath the rank leaves of an adder-plant glided a huge serpent. Its eyes were burning coals, its tongue a living flame. I was paralyzed with fear and powerless to move. Nearer and nearer it came. I felt its stifling breath displace the purer air. I saw its venomed fangs glist'ning in the pale moonlight. Rising from out its deadly coil it poised itself to strike, when suddenly a youth--a mortal, strangely present in that wild, weird spot, seeing the danger of the trembling bird, seized a dead bough, which chance had fashioned like a holy cross, and smote the foul thing dead. Then bore me safely from the charmed spot and gave me life and liberty!

sp.speaker: Dragonfin
sp.p: Revenge, revenge, on the minions of Zamiel. (Goes quickly off R.H.U.E.)

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: Revenge! Revenge!

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Nay, let no thought other than of joy mingle with this happy time. Remember, 'tis my natal hour, and I would have it, as in the past, a festal one. Let the invisible harmonies of this our realm breathe sweetest concord only.Song And you, bright Crystalline, with your fair sisters, chase with flying feet the silver hours.

div.stage: (Seats herself on bank C)

#Music#() The fairies form for Dance. After the first pose a loud, prolonged, warning note, as if from a shell, is heard outside at back. All start in alarm and those hold the attitude of listening. The sound is repeated. #Music#() hurry. The pose is broken and the Fairies, Gnomes, and Amphibea (the latter seizing their arms) form in alarm on either side. Dragonfin appears quickly through trap behind 1st set water and lands in front of ground piece.

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.stage: (Who at the first sound has sprung to her feet)
sp.p: Speak, what danger threatens?

sp.speaker: Dragonfin
sp.p: The sentinel shells, played upon by the watchful winds, give alarm. Two daring mortals, armed with the enchanted magnet of the Black Crook, approach the secret entrance. Already they have passed the white whirlpool in safety. They come to despoil our realm of its glittering wealth.

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Fear not the talisman they bear is powerless against the spells that guard the portal.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: Ho, ho, ho!

div.stage: (Echoed without and above)

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Is my Battalia at its post?

sp.speaker: Dragonfin
sp.p: The invisible guards of the entrance are marshalled for their destruction and white bones shall glisten far down among the red branches of the blood coral.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: Ho, ho, ho!

div.stage: (Echoed without and above)

delSpan.stage: Music(). Chorus by Gnomes, Amphibea and Fairies)

lg.l: Rejoice, rejoice, rejoice!
Sprites of the golden realm, rejoice.
Daring mortals mock our power,
Flushed with the drink that the heart makes bold,
Drunk with the thirst for the glittering gold,
They madly rush on the fatal hour.
Darks spells arise, smite their longing eyes
That they never may gaze on the glittering prize.
Rejoice, rejoice, rejoice!
Sprites of the golden realms rejoice!

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: My faithful subjects, your Queen commends the zeal with which you would guard from mortal sight our beauteous realm. But ere these rash intruders perish, I would gratify a strange desire. Speed hence, good Dragonfin, catch me their shadows from the bosom of the moon-lighted lake and cast them upon my faithful mirror. I would look upon them ere they fade forever.

div.stage: #Music#() Dragonfin prostrates himself before Stalacta, springs into the water and disappears.

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Begin the spell.

div.stage: #Music#() Chorus by fairies

lg.l: Mortal shadows dimly cast
By the mystic moonbeam's ray
On the bosom of the lake,
Hither, hither, fly away,
Flitting through the silver sheen
Come at summons of our Queen.
Guardian spirits let them pass.
Cast their shadows on the glass.

div.stage: Music(). Dragonfin springs from the water, and after prostrating himself before the Queen rises and points to the water. Music() Fairies wave their wands--a small arched headed frame of gold and coral stalactites rises centre at the distant entrance of the grotto, showing small figures of Rodolphe and Greppo in boat, the former at the prow gazing anxiously forward, the latter aft in the attitude of paddling.

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.stage: (Who had crossed down R.H. turns when the picture is fully shown--Chord--Starting

sp.p: Ha, 'tis he! He must not perish. Invisible spirits, avert this peril.

lg.l: Shades of mortals hovering near,
Join your masters--disappear.

div.stage: #Music#() hurry. The mirror and figures quickly sink.

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Dragonfin! Come hither. Fly with swiftest speed to the rocks beneath the waters of the guarded entramce. When the frail bark which now approaches shall be rent assunder by the relentless spells that guard our realm, be at your task to snatch from death these daring mortals and bear them safely hither.
Mistress!

lg.l: Nay, question me not, away, away,
Slaves of my power, obey, obey!

div.stage: #Music# hurry() Dragonfin bows low, springs into the water and disappears. #Music#(). A small boat with two mechanical figures representing Rodolphe and Greppo, as they appeared in the mirror, appears from R.H. outside at the distance entrance of the grotto, and moves very slowly across. When it reaches the centre of the opening it sinks at the sound of the gong and flash of lightning at back.

#Music#() hurry() All the Gnomes, Amphibea, etc. utter exclamations of delight and indulge in extravagant antics, until checked by a gesture from Stalacta. #Soft music#() Dragonfin rises slowly from water (C.) supporting on either side Rodolphe and Greppo, the latter gasping violently for breath as his head appears, they step on shore. Rodolphe and Greppo lost in bewilderment. Dragonfin bows low before Stalacta, the other Amphibea and Gnomes make a demonstration of attack.

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Forbear! Who moves again 'till I alone command, shall perish.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: (Rubbing his eyes) Is this a phantasm, this glittering gold, yon flashing gems, these strange fantastic shapes? Have I then passed the portal of an unknown world or am I dreaming?

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Welcome, brave mortal, to our bright domain, and you my subjects-- know and greet your Queen's preserver.

div.stage: #Music#(). Gnomes and Amphibea cluster around Rodolphe and Greppo, rolling at their feet and indulging in various grateful antics--After which the fairies surround them and evince their delight).

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: (Still bewildered) If this indeed be not a dream, tell me, bright being, you whose simple motion seems to sway the moods and passions of this elfin band, who art thou and where am I?

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: I am called Stalacta, Queen of this dazzling Realm. The glittering wonders that assail thine eyes are not creations of fantastic dreams, but Nature's handiwork wrought with cunning fingers in a bounteous mood.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Who has picked up a large mass of gold at back, comes forward 'Tis true, master, 'tis true. Behold this shining nugget.

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Who is thy droll companion?

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: My simple henchman, a faithful guide and servitor.

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: I bid him welcome for his master's sake.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Thanks, thanks, your resplendent majesty, thanks.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: You spoke of service done, have we then met before?

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Yes, once.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Indeed! When?

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: This very night.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: To night?

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: To night, in the Glen of Fire, but not as now. Then a poor weak, fluttering, charm-encompassed bird, you snatched me from the jaws of death, broke the dark spell of transformation and gave to me the priceless boon of liberty.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: I do remember.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: And so do I. Phew! How the sparks flew when master smashed the head of the scaly monster, and such a smell of brimstone. I do believe it was one of the Beelzebub's own imps in disguise.

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Again thou art welcome. This is my natal hour. Wilt view the sports of this our carnival?

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Most willingly.

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: And while the revels proceed thou shalt tell me thy story.

stage.delSpan: #Music#(). Seats are brought forward by Amphibea R.H. 1st Ent.. Stalacta and Rodolphe sit. Greppo disposes himself L.H. 1st Ent. Amusing himself with Dragonfin, Gnomes + Amphibea, who present him from time to time with nuggets of gold and jewels which he thrusts into his pockets until they become greatly distended,

during which action the diminutive sprites re-appear in shells on water floating to and fro, fishing. The fairies form for dance, as at first, Grand Ballet action by principals and full Corps de Ballet, during which the fishers in the shells are seen to catch some small silverfish.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: (after the dance terminates) Ha, ha! Dancing's all very well in its way, but there's the sport for me, fishing! Look, master, look, see how the little rogues hook the silly shiners. Oh, if there's one thing in the world I love more than another, it's fishing--such fun to feel the greedy rascals snap and see them wiggle. There's another. Oh I can't stand it any longer, fishing's like the measles, it's catching. (Turning to the Amphibea and Gnomes) Would any of you handsome gentlemen oblige me with a spare hook and line?

sp.speaker: Dragonfin
sp.stage: Nods assent and brings him rod and line

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Well, upon my word, I'm very much obliged to your scaly magnificence. I'll do as much for you some day. By the way, is your amphibious majesty fond of fish?

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: What kind?

sp.speaker: Dragonfin
sp.stage: Indicates that he likes large ones

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Like large ones, eh? All right, I'll make you a present of the first ten pounder I catch.

delSpan.stage: Music(). He fishes from the shore R.C. and catches two small fishes, the last quite dimunitive. The Amphibea, Gnomes and Fairies laugh boisterously as each fish is drawn forth.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Pshaw, mere sprats and sardines. Not my kind at all. This is too much like taking advantage of confiding innocence.
Couldn't your finny Excellency oblige me with a more tempting bait, something that would seduce some big, greedy, wiggly-waggly fellow into taking a nibble?

sp.speaker: Dragonfin
sp.stage: (Nods affirmatively.) Music(). He goes to the margin of the water and draws forth a large crab which he places in the hand of Greppo. It seizes him by the fingers, to the great delight of the Amphibea, Gnomes and Fairies. He struggles frantically to extricate himself & is finally released by Dragonfin who baits the hook with the crab and gives him the rod and line)

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: I don't know about this. Excuse me for asking the question, but, as an unprejudiced observer, don't you think this style of bait more likely to bite the fish than the fish to bite the bait?

sp.speaker: Dragonfin
sp.stage: (Shakes his head and indicates that a large fish will take it)

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: All right, here goes then.

delSpan.stage: Music() He casts the line into the water. A moment after it is violently seized and a frantic struggle ensues, during which he is nearly drawn overboard two or three times. Suddenly an amphibeous monster springs from the water and pursues Greppo around, off, and on the stage, to the great delight of the Amphibea, Gnomes & Fairies who indulge in boisterous laughter. Greppo in his terror throws himself at the feet of Stalacta for protection. She rises and waves her hand. The monster retires and is pacified by Dragonfin)

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Really, my fishy-fleshy friend, you must excuse me. I beg ten thousand pardons. I hadn't the remotest idea in the world that any of you bottle green gentlemen were lying around loose on the bottom watching for a supper of raw crabs. Indeed I hadn't.

delSpan.stage: The monster growls and makes a start. Music() Dragonfin interposes and pacifies the monster by patting him on the back, then taking his hand passes it into that of Greppo.)

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: All right, I accept your apology.

Now you're what I call a true friend--a friend in need. You stick by a fellow when he hadn't the courage to stick by himself. This is the second time you've done me a service. Once in saving me from too much water and now in saving me from too much luck, and I'll let you see that I can be grateful. You like fish?

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Consider him yours.
sp.stage: All the Amphibea, Gnomes & Fairies laugh and go up

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Thy story claims for thee my pity and my aid.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: And Hertzog, the Black Crook--

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Is a vile sorcerer whose dark unhallowed spells were wrought for thy destruction.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Beneath the entrance to this charmed spot lie intertwined amid the branches of the coraline whole hecatombs of human bones, the whitened relics of adventurous mortals who like thyself have sought this realm. Until tonight no human eye has ever seen the dazzling splendor of this wondrous dome. No human footsteps save thine own and his who follows thee have ever pressed these sands of gold. Had not thy coming been to me foreshadowed, and all my power been interposed to snatch thee from the impending doom, thou too had'st joined the hapless throng that mouldering lies beneath yon depths.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Then is thy debt to me already paid.

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Not so. I am still thy debtor and must ever be, thou art environed by danger and need the power of my protection. Return into the outer world again; thy happiness is there. She whom thou lov'st is worthy of thy love; therefore return.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Amina, dear Amina!

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: In the secret cells of this cavern whose walls are solid gold, lie counteless hoards of richest treasure, gleaned for ages by the tireless Gnomes. In the crystal depths of these waters sparkle gems richer by far than human eyes have ever gazed upon. Of these thou shalt bear with thee the choicest. Behold my gift.

delSpan.stage: Music(). A jewelled stalactiform etagere with strong light from calcium on it rises centre in front of ground-piece bearing upon its different shelves rich vases filled with gold and various colored jewels which Dragonfin, Gnomes, and Amphibea remove, performing a series of grotesque evolutions to marked Music(). Etagere sinks-- after which music. Stalacta waves her wand; a golden boat studded with jewels glides on from L.H. to L.C.)

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: This bark, protected by a potent spell shall bear thee safely to yon neighboring shore. My faithful gnomes shall be the treasure bearers. But ere we part, take thou this jewelled circlet.
sp.stage: (Gives him a ring from her finger)
sp.p: Should danger threaten as perchance it will, for baffled malice has a thousand stings, press but thy lips upon the gem and thou wilt find me by thy side.

delSpan.stage: Music(). Rodolphe kneels and kisses her hand

sp.speaker: Stalacta
sp.p: Farewell.

delSpan.stage: (Music(). He steps into the boat. Greppo, bearing a large mass of gold affectionately embraces Dragonfin, shakes hands with the Gnomes and Amphibea, kisses the Fairies, bows low to Stalacta and gets into the boat. A dolphin, glittering in green and gold, rises from behind 2nd or 3rd set water with principal danseuse bearing vase of treasure. Other dolphins float on R. + L. with diminutive sprites bearing treasure. Copious shower of gold, the other sprites on the water catching the flakes in silver shells. Poses by the gnomes, Amphibea and fairies. The whole scene brilliantly lighted. Tableaux and

div.add:
a power greater than mine for thy protection--I can give these riches beyond thy heart's desire, but am unable to restore thee to the outer world again--'Tis Neptune only can command the waters to give up the prisoners committed to their depths, but fear not mortal! For Stalacta's sake, the Sea King and his gentle Amphitite Queen of Beauty will give thee freedom from the spell of the Enchanter and command these glittering leaves to disappear amind the waves of mighty ocean! Hold! take this ring! Should danger threaten, press it to thy lips and thou shalt find Stalacta near to aid thee. #Music# Scene transforms to the ocean, and Neptune and the Sea Deities rise with
Rodolphe + Greppo
Tableau and
Slow Drop
div.stage: Slow Curtain

rdg.head: Act 3rd
rdg.stage: A lapse of six months.

Scene--Illuminated gardens of Wolfenstein by moonlight with Terrace and Illuminated castle at back. The latter half hidden by foilage. Set flowers and statuary, R. + L., at back. Set low plant in front of trap. R.H. 2nd Ent.
#Music# at rise of curtain. Masqueraders in Ball costume discovered promenading and conversing. Entrance and grand character dance by principals of the Ballet, after which the the masquers gradually disappear at different entrances.
Enter from the terrace L.H. Madam Barbara, masked, flauntingly dressed and carrying a huge fan. She is followed by Carline.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p:
(Unmasking and coming forward) Phew, what a relief. Thank the saints his Countship's birthday comes but once a year. Another such festival would be the death of me. Ah! I'm stewed, fried, boiled and roasted.
(Fans herself vigorously)

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: (Aside) And still as tough as Dame Gretchen's gander that was twenty one last Easter. (Aloud) Why, Madame Barbara, I thought you enjoyed it.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: So I do, child, so I do, particularly the masquerading. One has so many pleasant things whispered in one's ear, but I can't say much for the waltzing--it's such a terrible thing to take the starch out of one's linen.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p:
La, Madame Barbara, what's a little starch? Nothing! If I waltzed as gracefully as you--
(Barbara makes a gesture of satisfaction) and had such an inviting waist
(Barbara pinches her waist) I'd keep at it until I was as limp as a boiled cabbage leaf.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Then you--you think me graceful, eh?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: (Aside) As a hippopotamus. (Aloud) As a sylph. You were the envy of all the ladies and the admiration of all the other sex. Did you notice the courtly gentleman in the blue mask?

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: He who danced so often with the lady Amina?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Yes, madame.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: And what of him?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Nothing, only he was frantic to get an introduction to you.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: No was he?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Yes indeed, Madame, and when his Lordship the count engaged the Lady Amina for a moment, he turned to me, and slipping a golden crown into my palm with one hand, pressing his heart with the other, and pointing to you with the other asked with a sweet, sighing silvery voice, trembling with emotion, who is that lovely being?

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: No! Did he?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p:
Yes indeed, Madame.
(Aside) The saints forgive me for lying. (Aloud) And Mynheer Von Puffengruntz, who overheard him, turned pea-green with jealousy.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: (Fanning herself & pressing her hand upon her heart) Be still, little trembler, be still. I declare, my silly heart is fluttering like a poor little starling in a gold cage.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: (Aside) More like a big buzzard in a steel trap.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p:
Carline, take my fan, child.
(Gives it) The exertion will make my complexion too ruddy.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: So it will, Madame, and ruddy complexions are not genteel. Allow me. (Fans her vigorously)

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Not so violent, girl. You'll disarrange my hair. Gently, very gently, a sort of sportive zephyr.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: I understand, Madame. You want a mild sort of tickling sensation. Something like one feels on one's neck when a gentleman whispers in one's ear.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: (Languidly) Y-e-s. (Sighs) And he called me a-a-a-what did he call me?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: A swan-like creature.
A goose.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Oh. (Sighs) Who can he be I wonder.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Nobody appears to know, exactly. I heard his Lordship the Count whisper to the Baron von Stuffencram that he suspected the mysterious blue mask to be no other than the young prince Leopold. Once, while dancing, his domino came open at the breast and I saw a collar of jewels fit for an Emperor. Real dazzler that nearly blinded me. However, as everybody is to unmask at the grand banuqet, we will then know all about him.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Eh, what, the Prince Leopold?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: So his lordship the Count thinks.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Why he's already affianced, as everybody knows, to the young Princess Fredericka.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Dear me, so he is. How unfortunate!

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Poor young man, how I pity him. What a terrible thing it is to be of royal blood and not have the liberty to choose for one's self. Heigho! I know it is a sad, cruel, wicked thing to blight a young and budding affection, but as the right honorable foster-mother that is to be of her right honorable ladyship that is to be, I musn't encourage his highness in a hopeless passion. (displays herself)

rdg.stage: (Entering from terrace L.H. Von Puffengruntz)

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: There she is! What a grace. What a dignity. What a walk. (Coming foward L.H.) Ah-a-a!

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: (Sighing) There's another victim to love's cruel dart. My fan, child.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: (Giving it) Be careful, use it gently Madame; remember your complexion. (Aside) What a lovely couple--powder and puff.

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: (Aside) What a golden opportunity. (Aloud) Young woman, as I left the grand hall I heard your mistress asking for you.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Of course, I understand, cunning old walrus. (Aloud) May I return, Madame?

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Yes, but before you go you'd better leave with me the-- the reviving draught.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Reviving draught!--double distilled schnapps.
You'll find it in your pocket, Madam. Don't you remember, I gave it to you as we entered the garden.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Bless me, so you did. What with the waltzing on one side and my conquests on the other, I don't know whether I'm standing on my heels or my head. You can go! (Coquettes with her dress, etc.)

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: May I go now, Madam?

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p:
Yes, certainly child, that is if her ladyship requires you.
(Coquettes with her dress, etc.)

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: (Aside) I thought so, willing old pelican. She's beginning to dress her feathers already. Never mind, I shall have another flirtation with the Prince's equery, the drollest and most agreeable fellow in the world, and such a rogue.

rdg.stage: (Exit terrace L.H.)

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.stage: (L.H.) gazes admiringly at her, and sighs.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: (R.H.) casting sidelong glances at him) Heigho! There he is: My charms tonight have completed the conquest. He's fast bound in the bonds of rosy cupid. I see a proposal in one eye and a marriage settlement in the other. But I mustn't draw him in too suddenly. These men are like trout, they must be played with a little.

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: Full moon of the festival, why have you so cruelly robbed the grand hall of your light, and left us to grope about in the dull glimmer of the sickly stars.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Don't talk to me about moonshine and sickly stars, you heartless, gay deceiver.

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: Deceiver!

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Deceiver! Didn't I see you gallivanting with the fraulein Von Skragneck, the new Burgomaster's daughter?

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: Politeness, my dear Madame Barbara, merely politeness, on my honor. The fact is I-I had the misfortune to tread on the lady's favorite bunion, and what you mistook for tenderness was only an apology--an apology, believe me, my dear Madame Barbara, only an apology.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Oh, you men, you deceiving men, you are always ready with an excuse.

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: On the honor of a Von Puffengruntz, I swear I speak the truth. The fraulein Von Skragneck, indeed! Haven't I got eyes? Ah, cruel fair one, compared with her and all others, you are the stately sunflower in a meadow of dandelions. As-as-as the queenly hollyhock in a garden of chickweed.

rdg.stage: Music ( ) Tremulo piano--Dragonfin ascends quickly through trap behind low set plant R.H. 2nd. Ent. He steps forward and listens.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: It's coming at last, I know it's coming. (pressing her heart) What a strange flutter. I hope I'm not going to faint. Dear me, what poor, weak silly creatures we are. I must nerve myself for the trying occasion. How fortunate it is that I happen to have my smelling salts about me. (Draws flask from his pocket, turns back to Von Puff and drinks)

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: She's moved. She's overcome with emotion, she turns to hide her blushes. She yields, and now, like a conqueror, I'll gather in the fruits of victory.

rdg.stage: (He kneels with difficulty at the feet of Barbara, his face half-averted, and is about to take her hand when Dragonfin glides quietly between them, extends his left hand to Von Puffengruntz and takes Barbara's in the other. (They both sigh)

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.stage: (Squeezing the hand of Dragonfin who shakes with suppressed laughter)
sp.p: Poor, frightened thing, how she trembles.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Dear me, how strangely the tender passion affects him. He's shaking like an aspen and his hand is as cold as ice.

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: Bewitching syren, listen to the voice of love.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Oh, Mynheer Von Puffengruntz, how can you--

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: Don't call me Von Puffengruntz, call be Maximillian, call me your Maximillian. (Squeezes Dragonfin's hand; Dragonfin squeezes Barbara's)

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Oh, don't, you naughty man, you--you hurt my hand.

sp.speaker: Von Puff
