sp.p: No, did I? Queen of Love and Beauty, then let me heal the bruise. (Kisses the hand of Dragonfin rapturously who, at the same time, kisses Barbara's) And now that I've healed it let me call it mine. (Looks for the first time attentively at the hand, continues inspection up the arm until he encounters the grinning face of Dragonfin, when in speechless terror he drops the hand, makes various floundering attempts to regain his feet, and finally exits hurriedly L.H. 1st Ent.)

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Shall I keep him a little longer with Cupid's dart sticking in his bosom, or shall I end his misery.
Ahem, you'll-you'll never be a naughty boy again?

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: And you'll promise never to tread on the Fraulein Von Skragneck's favorite bunion?

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Poor fellow, joy has made him speechless; he can only answer with a squeeze of the hand.
Well then, Maximillian, I'm yours.
sp.stage: (Falls into Dragonfins's arms, looks up into his face. Music() Chord and hurry. She utters a piercing scream and rushes off R.H. 1st Ent.)

rdg.stage: Dragonfin indulges in extravagant antics until music changes, when he starts, inclines his ear to the ground and listens--rises, moves cautioously to R.H. 1st Ent., starts, points off R.H. shakes his clenched hand threateningly, and quickly disappears through trap R.H.)

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: (Entering R.H. 1st Ent. hurriedly & disturbed.) Foiled, tricked, crossed in the hour of my victory. A life desperately played for and fairly won, snatched from the jaws of death. He lives, my chosen victim lives, and flushed with triumph and vast hoards of gold, stalks boldly forth to mock me. Oh, curse the interposing power the stepped between us. A withering palsy light upon her arm, and blight and pestilence infect the air she breathes! Oh impotent--oh, driveling fool! To work, to work! A soul once tampered with must be pursued, not cast aside to tempt another. So runs the bond to which I've sealed. 'Tis well, 'tis well. I'll track him as the sleuth hound tracks the stag. He must be, shall be mine!

rdg.stage: Music() Exit hurriedly L.H. 1st Ent.
Music(). Re-enter masquers R.+.L at back. They cross and disappear)
(Enter L.H. from Terrace, Carline, laughing immoderately. She is followed by Greppo, who is dressed in a smart but outre livery)

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: No, no, Master Equerry, that won't do. You are very clever, very droll and you tell very funny stories, but that last joke is a trifle too much.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: But my dear Susetta--

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: (Laughing) There, there. I knew you were not in earnest. My name's not Susetta.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Of course it isn't. It's- it's- what is it?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: No it isn't "What is it," It's Carline.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Of course it is, but you see I always mean Carline when I say Suesetta. Therefore Susetta--that is my dear Carline, when I tell you I love you--

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: (laughing) I don't believe a word you say. Why you arrived here scarely three hours ago, and you've already been making love to half the girls in the castle.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: It's a mistake, my dear Susetta--I mean Carline, altogether a mistake. I had my eye on you from the first, and any little outside pleasantry you may have happened to notice were only to get my hand in.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: And this is only to keep it in, I suppose. No, no. I'm not as simple as I look, and I tell you, clever master Equerry, it won't do.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: But my dear Carline, allow me to tell you that I'm not an equerry.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p:
No.
(Drawing himself up) I'm consulting secretary, confidential adviser, Portable treasury, and principal disbursing officer to his highness the Prince.
(Aside)
Everybody takes master to be a Prince and it's no part of my business to undeceive them. Besides if he isn't a Prince he deserves to be, and I ought to be his Prime Minister.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Dear me, Consulting Secretary?

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Consulting Secretary.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Confidential Adviser?

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Confidential Adviser.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Portable Treasury?

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p:
Portable Treasury. Behold!
(Showing two glittering purses) Here are two purses, my master's and my own. From this, (Showing one nearly empty) by the Prince's order came the gold I scattered among the servants in the courtyard. With this
(Showing full one) I intend to endow the maiden of my choice.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: And you really mean--

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: That you are she.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Yes!

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: I'm afraid to trust you.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Allow me to make a deposit. (gives purse)

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Oh, dear, you've taken away my breath.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: No, have I? Permit me to return it to you. (Kisses her) Now listen, my dear little Carline, I have a secret and as there should be no secrets between man and wife--that is, man and wife that are to be, I'm going to share it with you.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: A secret, dear Greppo?

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Dear Greppo! Oh, say that again.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Well then, dear Greppo.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Oh, thank you. You needn't repeat it again at present. That's as much as I can stand 'till I get used to it.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Well, then, the secret.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Yes. In the first place, do you love your mistress, Carline?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Love her? I'd die for her.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: No, no, no, no. I don't want you to go quite so far as that. I'm not ambitious to be a widower before I've had my honeymoon.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Well, then, I love her dearly.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: That's better. And she loves my mas--that is this young Rodolphe, the painter?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Better than her own life, poor dear lady.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: And would marry him but for this ruffianly Count Wolfenstein?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Yes--but the secret.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Well, then, you must know--
Hark, somebody's coming.

rdg.stage: (Enter from Terrace L.H. Rodolphe and Amina He is brilliantly dressed, wearing a collar and other ornaments of glittering jewels-blue mask and domino. Amina also wears mask and domino.

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Some one is here.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Fear not; they are our own people. (Comes forward R.H. with Amina) Leave us, good Greppo, and take your companion with you.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Yes, good master. Come along, Carline.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Surely I've heard that voice before?

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Hush. That's the secret I was going to share with you, and if you'll take a stroll with me in the ramble that leads to the Lover's Paradise I'll tell you all about it.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Yes, dear Greppo.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: Oh, don't!

rdg.stage: Music at rise of Curtain
Laughing Chorus.
rdg.head: Act 3rd
Scene 1.
rdg.stage: Palace Interior of Wolfenstein
Music as curtain rises. Everybody discovered in masquerading costumes, with dominos carrying masks etc.
All the Characters are surrounding Hertzog laughing and jeering at his deformity, he is enraged, but cannot remove his mask for fear of being recognized.
Laughing Duet and Chorus from "Les Brigands" by Carline, Casper, and Chorus, at the end of which all dance off leaving Hertzog when alone he tears off mask.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Curses on ye! laughing Idiots! but that I have more serious work in hand, your mirth would change to wailing! Lo! this Rudolph has escaped my snare. I am foiled in the moment of my success, by the Fairy of the Grotto who will doubtless oppose all my schemes for the destruction of my victim! -- She has not only saved his life but has enriched him with countless treasure!--He has dared to enter these walls and share in this high festival given by Count Wolfenstein to celebrate his betrothal to Amina--and the great ones of the land are paying homage to the beggarly painter, believing him a wealthy Prince!--Curses on Stalacta! palsies wither her! Pestilence and blight infect the air she breathes!--Ah! Fool that I am to waste the precious moments in impotent rage! Curses will not kill, nor hatred injure them! My magic arts must aid my vengeance! to work! to work!--Zamiel! Prince of darkness thou wily not desert thy votary now!
Yes Rudolph! laugh. dance, woo and be merry! Your triumph shall be short--my vengeance swift and sure--at midnight you must die! ha! ha! Zamiel upon thee I call for aid!

rdg.stage: #Music# hurried--Exit Hertzog R.H. Music Changes and Masqueraders gallop round stage leaving two ladies who dance character dance and Exeunt. Enter Barbara and Carline R.H.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: (fanning herself) Thank the Fates! Such festivals as this come not often-- I am stewed like a young duck!

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: And yet, tough as an old goose. Aloud Why Madame Barbara, I thought you were enjoying the fete amazing I never saw you more lively and entertaining--or in higher spirits!

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Why yes child--I try to appear to enjoy myself, out of compliment to the Count and Countess that is to be.--and I don't dislike the eating and drinking, or the lovemaking.--it is so amusing to see what fools the male creatures make of themselves--but I can't say I enjoy the waltzing.--it's ruinous to a delicate complexion--is my face much flushed child?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: La! Madame Barbara! You are only improved by a little heightened color.--for my part I wouldn't mind being red as a peony if I could move through the dance as gracefully as you do.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: I am more than ever persuaded Carline is a very sensible girl! (aloud) do you think me graceful child?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: What I think Madame Barbara signifies little; what but if you heard the admiration of the young gentlemen--

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Oh fie! For shame Carline!--You mustn't tell me of such things--what young gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: He in the blue domino for instance--he who is, they say a Prince--I wonder if he is...I couldn't see his face-- but he has a way with him that makes me think I have seen him before.--however he has been following you all the evening-- (aside) while the Lady Amina was under your wing.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: I remarked his assiduities child, and got rid of him by a stratagem--I requested him to dance with my daughter Amina.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: That was a clever trick Madame.--I warrant me he consented readily enough--how cunningly you escape him Madame Barbara.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: From a sense of duty, child! I don't wish to make Herr Von Puffengruntz jealous you know.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Bless me! I think there's no amusement equal to making a lover jealous.-- I am going to try how it succeeds with mine.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Thoughtless and impudent girl! You don' mean to say you have a lover at your age?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Oh! Please Madame Barbara, don' be angry with me he only loves me a very little bit.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: And who is this moderate lover pray?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Young Casper, who guides travelers across the Brocken.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: And why do you wish to make him jealous?

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: Because I caught him kissing Susette--I'll let him see that two can play at that game. There's that handsome young man, the Equerry to the Prince, at least we suppose he is a Prince, he has been plaguing me all the evening,--such a beautiful dancer--he waltzes like a humming top!

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Well take care his waltzing doesn't turn your silly little head!-- I declare here are my daughter Amina and the Stranger Prince again-- I must fly!

rdg.stage: Exit R.H.

sp.speaker: Carline
sp.p: I do wonder who that Stranger is, but at twelve o'clock every one must unmask--and then my curiosity will be gratified!

div.stage: (Music(). Exeunt 1st Ent. L.H.
Rodolphe and Amina unmask

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Oh, dear Rodolphe, is this a dream?

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: What is past seems so, but day has dawned on our long clouded night and this the awaking.

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Your story is indeed most wondrous. But on, dear Rodolphe, I tremble for your life! If you should be discovered the vengeance of the ruthless Wolfenstein, backed by his horde of fierce retainers would be terrible.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Fear not, I will defend my right with my life. The same kind power that interposed between me and destruction protect us still. You shall be saved. All is ready for our flight. On the border of the forest, beyond the boundary of the gardens, swift horses are concealed. After midnight the moon veiling her face behind the Brocken, will cast a deep shadow over the valley. When all is quiet I will be beneath your window. The rest is easy. Carline and my faithful Greppo will accompany us.

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: (Throwing her arms around him) Oh, my Rodolphe, my more than life, coming this suddenly from the darkness of my despair into the sunlight of this new-born hope, dazzles me. My eyelids close. I cannot look this great joy in the face. I fear to call it mine.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Fear?

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Fear with that fear which springs from woman's love.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Be calm, sweet love, be brave, and all will yet be well.

div.stage: Music--piano() Laughter heard outside at back)

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Hark, the masquers come this way. Let's mingle with the throng.

div.stage: (They mask & cross to L.H. 1st Ent.)

Music louder(). Maskers enter L.+R. laughing and conversing, remaining R.H. at back. While so engaged and after all are on, Music changes to hurry()
Hertzog with drawn sword enters hurriedly at terrace L.H. followed by guards, Wolfenstein with drawn sword, Wulfgar, Bruno, and last, Von Puffengruntz with Barbara, the two latter remaining on Terrace. Hertzog down R.H. 1st Ent. glaring on Rodolphe.

sp.speaker: Wolfenstein
sp.p: (Centre at foot of Terrace steps) Let no one stir; guard every avenue that leads from hence. (To guests) Bear with me, friends, there's treason in our midst.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: Treason?

sp.speaker: Wolfenstein
sp.p: 'Tis said a serf, a wretch, usurping the semblance of a noble prince and bent on outrage has dared to mingle with this goodly throng. If that be false to all I'll make amends for this rude breaking in upon the general joy. If it be true 'tis fit we know it. Therefore I do command that all shall here unmask.

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Lost! lost!

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Aye, let all unmask.

div.stage: (All unmask. Rodolphe in doing so, throws off his domino, draws his sword, and places himself before Amina. (Chord)

sp.speaker: Wolfenstein
sp.p: 'Tis true! Yield, audacious miscreant!

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Never, while life remains!

sp.speaker: Wolfenstein
sp.p: Upon him, guards, hew him to pieces!

div.stage: Music(). Ladies scream. Amina faints and falls into the arms of Greppo who enters L.H. 1st Ent. Wolfenstein and Guards are rushing upon Rodolphe.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: The ring, Master, the ring.

div.stage: Rodolphe kisses the ring. Foot, border and wing lights flashed quickly up. Stalacta springs from L.H.1st Ent in glittering mail, with helmet, sword, and shield, followed by Dragonfin, armed with a trident. Fairies and nymphs as Amazons with breast plates, helmets, shields and javelins. L.H. 1st Ent. Gnomes and amphibea with knotted clubs and tridents from L.H. 2nd and 3rd Entrances, and on terrace R. + L. Wolfenstein, Guards, and gentlemen shrink back appalled. Hertzog stands the embodiment of baffled rage. Von Puffengruntz on Terrace faints and falls into the arms of Barbara, who fans him--Tableaux and
Quick curtain

Note--from the cue "Hew him to pieces.", the whole action must be rapid and simultaneous. Foot and stage lights flashed quickly up when Rodolphe kisses the ring. When curtain drops 1st time, hold the picture to answer encore.

div.head: Act 4th
div.stage: A lapse of six months.
Scene 1st--An apartment in the Castle of Wolfenstein, in 1.
Music (). Enter Barbara, R.H.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Alas that things ever fall so ill. 'Tis now six months since that never-to-be-forgotten night, and still no news of the lost mistress of Wolfenstein. Nor yet of his Lordship, who has sworn a dreadful oath never to return to the castle until he has brought her back and revenged himself on the horrible monster who has stolen her. And that graceless baggage Carline, too, to go off at the same time, leaving all the cares of the household to fall on my poor shoulders. And then to make matters worse, spells and witchcraft turn all things upside down. The cows milk vinegar, the wells are dry, the hens lay addled eggs---

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: (Entering R.H. with very red nose & tipsey) And all the wine's turned sour.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: (Looking ruefully at him) There's another comfort. To think that I, the right honorable foster-mother that was to have been to her right honorable Ladyship that was to have been--for whom many a young and tender heart has sighed in vain--should ever have thrown herself away upon a wine-butt.

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: (Hic) A wine-butt, Madam Von Puffengruntz?

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Aye, a wine-butt, a beer barrel, a brute that hasn't drawn a sober breath since the day after we were married--now more than three months ago.

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: (Hic) A beer-barrel?

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: (Savagely) I said a beer-barrel.

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: (Hic) Certainly, of course, just whichever you please, my dear, wine-butt or beer-barrel, it's all the same to me. You know you will cackle.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Cackle!

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: (Hic) Cackle, my dear. You know I never have a moment's peace. You're not even quiet when you're asleep. You snore, Madam Von Puffengrunz, you snore, loud enough to split the drum of my ear and rip up the seam up my nightcap.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Snore, you wretch, I snore?

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: (Hic) Yes, my dear, and have the nightmare. (Hic) I don't like a wife that snores and I hate a wife that has the nightmare. In future I'm going to have separate apartments. Hereafter I intend to sleep alone.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Alone!

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: (Hic) I said alone.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: Am I awake? Who and what do you take me for?

sp.speaker: Von Puff
sp.p: (Hic) I took you for a gentle spice-a sort of seasoning to the dull life I led here in the castle, but damn it, Madam, you've turned out to be all the condiments in one, a bottom layer of mustard, a top dressing of cayenne pepper and a subeterranean lake of vinegar in the middle.

sp.speaker: Barbara
sp.p: (Enraged and approaching him) he retreats around L.H.) Cackle! Snore! Nightmare! Separate apartments! Cayenne pepper! You wretch! You--you sot! You villain. I'll pepper you! (Pulls his wig off) There, take that, and that, and that. (Beats him over the poll with it 'till both off, L.H.)

div.stage: Curtain

div.head: Scene 2nd
div.stage: The retreat of Rodolphe in the Forest of Bohemia. (in 2) Music() at opening. Distant sound of hunter's horn and echo.
(Enter Rodolphe and Amina followed by Greppo. The two first are in hunting costume.)

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: (Throwing his spear and horn to Greppo) I weary with the chase, call together our people and bid them lead our horses to where the forest path crosses the brook, there we will join them.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: 'Tis wisely resolved, good master. The sun declines, night comes on apace and we are yet some three good miles from home, besides I'm hollow as a drum, moreover, in early autumn venison keeps not overlong and the fat haunch of yonder noble stag cries out for speedy roasting. Pray do not tarry long.

div.stage: (Exit L.H. 2nd Ent)

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Well, dear love, tomorrow ends the year of our probation. Tomorrow, at the holy altar's foot, I call you mine.

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: Tomorrow! How brief the time and yet how long 'till then. Oh, Rodolphe, will it come to us? There seems to be a lurking danger in the air, a cloud between us and the coming light.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Fear not. Here in the deep seculsion of our forest home we are safe from all pursuit. (Distant horn and echo L.H. at back.) Hark! 'tis Greppo calling in the huntsmen. Let's on to meet him.

div.stage: Music () They are crossing to R.H. when they are suddenly confronted by Hertzog, Wolfenstein and Wulfgar, who enter quickly R.H. 2nd Ent. (Chord)

sp.speaker: Wolfenstein
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! At last we meet!

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: (Starting back and drawing his sword) Entrapped! Fly, Amina, seek safety with our people. My arm shall bar pursuit.

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: No, Rodolphe, we will die together.

sp.speaker: Wolfenstein
sp.p: Alive, take him alive! Yield!

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: (Standing on his defense) He who takes my sword must win it.

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Put up thy blade; she whom thou would'st invoke is powerless to aid.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p:
False wretch, but that another life hangs on the slender thread of mine--though coward numbers swarmed on every side--I'd try this issue with my single sword. But know thou still art juggled with. The power I once invoked is potent still.
Music() He kisses the ring--Stalacta springs from thicket L.H. flat in glittering full armor, Dragonfin through L.H. trap or on from L.H. 2nd Ent.)
Behold, we meet on equal ground!

sp.speaker: Wolfenstein
sp.p: Though environed by a thousand fiends my hate would find a way to reach you.

div.stage: Music(). Grand triple sword combat: Rodolphe and Wolfenstein. Stalacta and Hertzog. Dragonfin and Wulfgar. Wolfenstein and Wulfgar are slain. Hertzog wounded and dismayed flies R.H. 2nd Ent. Amina, who during the combat has knelt in prayer, throws herself into the arms of Rodolphe then both kneel at the feet of Stalacta. Dragonfin indulges in grotesque exultation over the bodies of Wolfenstein and Wulfgar--Picture.
Closed in.

div.head: Scene 3rd
div.stage: (The Forest in 1).
Enter RODOLPHE RH supporting Amina.

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Look up, Amina, all dangers past, courage, ere long, we'll meet our people.

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: And you are safe?

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Safe! Come, poor trembling dove. Courage, courage.

div.stage: (Music() Exeunt L.H.
Music() Enter R.H. Hertzog, infuriate)

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Let one vast curse fill all the air! Am I then juggled with! Malignant powers, obey your master's call. Viewless Spirits of Evil, work now your direst spells! As toppling mountains crush the mighty pines, crush thou the power that thwarts and mocks me. Zamiel, mighty master, I invoke thy aid.

div.stage: Music() Thunder. Two fiends enter quickly R.+L. bearing lighted flambeau.

sp.speaker: Fiends
sp.p: Your will?

sp.speaker: Hertzog
sp.p: Summon your infernal legions. Pursue yon flying pair-- Fire the forest, girdle them with a belt of flame; close every avenue of escape. Away! Away!

div.stage: Music() Thunder. Fiends salaam and rush off L.H. followed by Hertzog.
Change
Curtain

div.head: Scene 4th
div.stage: Burning forest--a grand & comprehensive conflagation scene, in 2) Lights down. Music() at opening of Scene. Loud crackling noise (torpedoes) and red fire on both sides. Rodolphe and Amina Enter L.H.2nd Ent. as they attempt to escape they are driven back from R. + L. by fiends with flaming torches.

sp.speaker: Amina
sp.p: (In agony) I burn! I suffocate!

sp.speaker: Rodolphe
sp.p: Courage, courage. The Ring! The Ring!

div.stage: (He kisses the ring--Gong sounds, a rock opens in L.H. flat disclosing a grotto of silver Stalactites. They quickly enter. Hertzog and the fiends spring forward, when Stalacta steps forward from the opening, holding aloft a glittering cross. Hertzog & the Fiends shrink back. Tableaux
Closed in

div.head: Scene 5th
div.stage: The forest by night. (in 1) Lights down. Sound of Hunters horn R.H. and very faint echo. Greppo enters R.H.

sp.speaker: Greppo
sp.p: What's the use? Now--what is the use? The oftener I call the fainter comes the answer. Here it is quite dark, Master waiting for the horses and I wandering about like a Jack o' Lantern, following the horn of some goblin huntsman. There's some devil's work going on. I know there's some devil's work going on. (Starting) I beg his infernal Majesty's pardon. I hope I haven't said anything to offend, but strange sights and sounds are in the air. Birds that ought to have gone to roost an hour ago, fly screaming from tree to tree. The dismal screech-owl, from his hole in the oak answers to the croak of the dreary monk-raven, and just now I saw a big fat buck scampering through the forest with his tail on fire. Oh, dear, oh daer, what fearful omens. And I'm to be married tomorrow. If anything should happen to me--if my poor dear, darling little Carline should happen to be left a widow before she's made a wife--if I should never taste--that is, if I should never know--Oh, Lord, it won't bear thinking of. I'll try once more. (Winds the horn--Echo without scarely audible) Worse and worse. Oh Lord, Oh Lord. I want to go home. Exit L.H. Change

div.stage: Curtain

div.head: Scene 6th
div.stage: (Pandemonium (in 2 or 3) Zamiel in Council, seated on an illuminated throne of skulls and flame. C, at back. To R. + L. of C. lesser thrones, that on the right occupied by Redglare, with pen and open book, that on the left by a Secretary writing. At the foot of the central throne two dwarf-demon pages with wands in attendance.

(Music() at opening of scene--Fiends discovered in a chorus of demoniacal yells and fiendish laughter dancing around a flaming chasm. After the action is continued a brief time, Zamiel waves his sceptre--Demons separate and form R.+L.

sp.speaker: Zamiel
sp.p: 'Tis well. Let silence reign awhile. How stands the record of the dying year? Has every seed brought sinful fruit? Is all the harvest gathered in--is every bond fulfilled?

sp.speaker: Redglare
sp.p: All, all save one.

sp.speaker: Zamiel
sp.p: Who plays the laggard?

sp.speaker: Redglare
sp.p: One who sought to rival thy great power. Hertzog the Black Crook.

sp.speaker: All the Fiends
sp.p: Ho, ho, ho.

div.stage: (Echoed without and above, followed by a single wild blast of infernal music)

sp.speaker: Zamiel
sp.p: If, when the brazen tongue of clamorous Time, now trembling on the midnight verge, proclaims the appointed hour, the wail of the fresh soul by him betrayed, breaks on the air of Hell, let him be summoned.

div.stage: Music(). The demons utter a wild wail of delight and resume the dance. The gong strikes twelve. At the first stroke, the demons cease dancing and hold separate pictures of exulatation. At the termination of each stroke, a single brazen blast of demoniacal Music.() At the twelfth strok loud and continuous thunder. Demons utter a wild cry. Zamiel rises and waves his sceptre. (If possible the scene breaks away and discovers vistas of Pandemonium in 3, teeming with infernal life and wreaths of flame, from which appear illuminated heads of demons, skeletons, and nondescript Monsters.) div.head: Scene 7th
div.stage: Subterranean Gallery of Emerald and crystal stalactites in 1.) Music at opening of Scene(). Characteristic march. Grand procession of Amphibea and Gnomes bearing in their arms and upon their heads salvers, shells and quaint vases filled with gold and jewels. They are followed by Amazons in armor, led by Stalacta.
